Award.AwardTitle: Dynamic Redistribution of Fluids in Porous Media
Award.AbstractNarration:
Most subsurface activities perturb the natural state of fluids in soil and rock because fluids are often injected, withdrawn or transported through the subsurface. All of these techniques induce changes in the local pressure field that initially perturb a multiphase system into a nonequilibrium condition that, over time, relaxes to steady-state or quasi-static distributions. The relaxation depends on pore-scale processes such as dynamic contact angles, air-water interface geometry, temporal changes in wettability, and local heterogeneities in the porous media. This research focuses on an experimental investigation of the dynamic redistribution of fluids in porous media by connecting internal microscopic perturbations to external macroscopic behavior. The study will assess the contributions of wettability, pore topology and films to the redistribution of immiscible fluids in a porous medium in the transition from dynamic to steadystate/quasi-static conditions. A combination of experimental techniques will be used that include the fabrication of transparent micro-models with built-in electro-kinetic actuators tomanipulate fluids at the pore scale internal to the pore network; the fabrication of 3D transparent micro-models using a new grain deposition method; and the measurement of 2D & 3D fluid distributions using fluorescent imaging and laser confocal microscopy to determine the role of absorbed films, corner fluids and pinned films on static and dynamic relations as a function of dimensionality. Analysis of experimental datasets will determine which competing theories for static and dynamic constitutive relationships are supported by experimental evidence, and whether current theories are sufficient to describe multiphase fluid relaxation.

Understanding the scaling of pore connectivity and the hydraulic properties of porous networks is of particular relevance today because of the intense activity in shale-gas which depends on networks of fractures to produce the gas, and because of attempts to sequester carbon dioxide in the subsurface. In addition, contaminant remediation efforts, chemical mixing, and biological tissue growth on synthetic porous media all depend on the complex interplay of geometry with the dynamics of fluids. This research will provide critical testing of theoretical methods used to predict flow and distributions of multiple fluids in porous media, and will enable scientists and
engineers to connect interfacial areas, disconnected fluid phases and film geometry to macroscopic hydraulic properties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most subsurface activities perturb the natural state of fluids in soil and rock because fluids are often injected, withdrawn or transported through the subsurface.  All of these techniques induce changes in the local pressure field that initially perturb a multiphase system into a non-equilibrium condition but, over time, relax to steady-state or quasi-static distributions. The time to relax to a “static” or “quasi-static” configuration of fluids and fluid-fluid interfaces depends on pore-scale processes such as dynamic contact angles, air-water interface relaxation and temporal changes in wettability, as well as local heterogeneities in the porous media and fluid properties.

In this study, contributions of wettability and pore topology to the redistribution of immiscible fluids in a porous medium was study for quasi-static conditions. The objectives  were achieved by using transformative experimental techniques that involved the fabrication of transparent micro-models with built-in electro-kinetic actuators for manipulating fluids at the pore scale internal to a pore network.   Electro-kinetic methods provide a technique for remotely changing the contact angle of the fluid-fluid interface with a solid  (Figure 1 Contact Angle vs. Voltage).  Electro-kinetically induced changes in contact angle reduced the capillary pressure during drainage (Figure 2 Capillary Pressure -Sautration) but do not affect the externally measured pressure during imbibition. A comparison of hysteresis loop with/without voltage exhibits a difference of ~20 Pa in the drainage scan while almost the same in the imbibition scan.  The change in energy represented by the hysteresis loop with and without voltage (or for different wettabilities) is on the order of 70 nano-Joules.  Electro-kinetic methods also provide a method for measuring nano-scale energy changes that result in de-pinning of fluid-fluid interfaces caused by surface roughness (Figure 3 Saturation versus Time).  Nano-scale changes in energy are sufficient to affect fluid distribution and saturation in a simple wedge-shaped channel but do not affect the externally measured pressure.  Changes in the interfacial area per volume compsensate for the change in fluid saturation.

Multi-electrode electro-kinetic micro-models were also developed enable control over local and global wettability.  Using different combination of elextrodes, different regions of a pore would have different wettability (i.e. different contact angles). Local variations in surface wettability affect global measurements of capillary  pressure - saturation relationship (Figure 4 Effect of Local Wettability).  

Our laboratory measurements on 2D micro-models with innovative built-in actuators provide insight into the connection between micro-scale geometric and surface properites of pores to macroscopic hydraulic properties. This expermental approach defines a new method for critical testing of theoretical methods used to predict flow and distributions of multiple fluids in porous media. Understanding the scaling of pore connectivity and the hydraulic properties of porous networks is particularly relevant today with the interest in shale-gas which requires networks of fractures to produce the gas, as well as applications related to secure sequestration of carbon dioxide in the subsurface, contaminant remediation efforts, chemical mixing, and biological tissue growth on synthetic porous media.
